bestBHT.bht: Some rabbis allowed an unfaithful son to prevent the use of money for the support of his parents by simply saying Corban, signifying that what they might have expected from him had been devoted to sacred uses. This clever trick justified the son's deception and deprived his parents of much-needed assistance. The term Corban referred to offerings and gifts to God, specifically those without a sacrifice. This highlights the Pharisaical mindset that valued religious traditions over familial obligations and genuine care for others.

Henry Alford: 11.] Corban, an offering without a sacrifice.
Marvin Vincent: Corban. Mark only gives the original word, and then translates. See on Matthew 14:5.
Philip Schaff: Corban. This was the Hebrew word used, which Mark translates into Greek for his Greek readers. Both mean a gift to God.
The term ‘Corban’ seems to have included all kinds of offerings, though some think it was applied in the time of Christ only to offerings without a sacrifice.
On the whole verse, see Matthew 15:5-6.
Archibald T. Robertson: The rabbis actually allowed the mere saying of this word by an unfaithful son to prevent the use of needed money for the support of father or mother.
It was a home thrust to these pettifogging sticklers for ceremonial punctilios.
They not only justified such a son's trickery, but held that he was prohibited from using it for father or mother, but he might use it for himself.
John Gill: Whoever made use of that word to his father or his mother, signifying thereby, that what they might have expected relief from at his hands, he had devoted it; or it was as if it was devoted to sacred uses; adding, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me, [he shall be free].
This was not the form of an oath, or swearing by Corban, or the sacred treasury in the temple... it was a vow he made, that what he had, should be as Corban, as a gift devoted to sacred uses.

That as that could not be appropriated to any other use, so his substance, after such a vow, could not be applied to the relief of his parents; though he was not obliged by it to give it for the use of the temple, but might keep it himself, or bestow it upon others.

bhtAttempts.bht: Some rabbis allowed an unfaithful son to prevent the use of money for the support of his parents by simply saying the word Corban, signifying that what they might have expected relief from had been devoted to sacred uses. This was a clever trick to withhold support from one's parents while appearing righteous. It was a form of manipulation that not only justified the son's trickery, but also deprived his parents of much-needed assistance. The term Corban referred to offerings and gifts to God, and it seems that during the time of Christ, it was exclusively used to describe offerings without a sacrifice. This verse exposes the Pharisaical mindset that prioritized religious traditions over the genuine care and support of family members.

This verse exposes the Pharisaical mindset that prioritized religious traditions over the genuine care and support of family members.

This clever trick justified the son's deception and deprived his parents of much-needed assistance. The term Corban referred to offerings and gifts to God, specifically those without a sacrifice. Some rabbis allowed an unfaithful son to prevent support for his parents by saying Corban, meaning what they expected to receive was devoted to sacred uses. This trick justified the son's deception and denied his parents much-needed help. Corban referred to offerings and gifts to God, particularly those without a sacrifice. This reveals the Pharisaical mindset that prioritized religious traditions over familial responsibilities and genuine compassion for others.

The rabbis actually allowed the mere saying of this word by an unfaithful son to prevent the use of needed money for the support of father or mother, highlighting the clever nature of this deceitful practice. By uttering the word Corban, individuals were able to withhold assistance from their parents while still appearing righteous. The term Corban referred to offerings and gifts to God. This verse demonstrates the Pharisaical mindset that prioritized adherence to religious customs over the duty of caring for family members in need.
